questions.text: A young male patient undergoes a submucosal resection. One week later, he presents with bilateral nasal obstruction and pressure sensation over the nasal bridge. On examination, smooth, rounded swelling of the septum is seen bilaterally. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis is a septal hematoma. 

Septal hematoma occurs when there is an accumulation of blood beneath the periosteum or perichondrium of the nasal septum. The most common cause of hematoma is nasal surgery or trauma. However, it is also seen in individuals with bleeding disorders. 

Patients present with bilateral nasal obstruction, frontal headache, and pressure sensation over the bridge. 

Examination, as seen in this patient, will show bilateral smooth rounded swellings of the nasal septum. If palpated, the mass will be soft and fluctuant.

The following image shows the bilateral, smooth, rounded swellings of the nasal septum indicative of septal hematoma. 

Treatment of septal hematomas involves aspiration with a wide bore needle if small, and incision and drainage if large. The incision can be made parallel to the nasal floor. Removing a small piece of nasal mucosa will aid in drainage. After drainage, the nose has to be packed bilaterally to avoid reaccumulation. 

Other options: 

Option A - Septal abscess occurs usually when there is a secondary infection of a septal hematoma. It is characterized by fever, chills, and frontal headaches. 

Option C - Septal perforation can occur after nasal surgery. Features depend on the size of the perforation. Smaller perforations can present with whistling while the larger perforations will present with epistaxis and crust formation. An image of septal perforation is given below.

Option D - Septal deviation is characterized by chronic unilateral or bilateral nasal obstruction. There is usually an external deformity and associated sinusitis, epistaxis, and anosmia.

Related Pearl: Septal Haematoma

  • Septal hematoma is a collection of blood under the perichondrium or periosteum of the nasal septum
  • Causes: Trauma, septal surgery and bleeding disorders
  • Clinical features: Bilateral nasal obstruction (most common presenting feature), frontal headache
  • Treatment:
    • Aspiration of small hematomas
    • Incision and drainage of large hematomas followed by nasal packing
    • Systemic antibiotics to prevent abscess formation
  • Complications: Septal abscess, depression of dorsum, permanently thickened septum

Related Pearl: Nasal Septum

Septum proper is an osseocartilaginous framework made up of:

  • Septal or quadrilateral cartilage
  • Perpendicular plate of ethmoid
  • Vomer
  • Others – crest of nasal bones, nasal spine of frontal bone, rostrum of sphenoid, crest of palatine bones and the crest maxilla, and the anterior nasal spine of maxilla

questions.text: A 49-year-old female from Nagaland presented with right-sided hearing loss. On examination, a dull right  tympanic membrane is noted. Enlarged lymph nodes are seen in the posterior triangle of the neck. Which of the following is the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with right-sided hearing loss, dull tympanic membrane (middle ear effusion leading to a conductive hearing loss) and enlarged lymph nodes in the posterior triangle of the neck (cervical lymphadenopathy) is indicative of nasopharyngeal carcinoma. Radiotherapy is the treatment of choice.

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is extremely radiosensitive, hence treatment of local and regional disease is invariably radiotherapy. 

  • Stage I and II are treated by radiotherapy alone while
  • Stage III and IV require concomitant radiation and chemotherapy or radiation followed by chemotherapy.

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is a malignant tumor of the nasopharynx. The theories for etiology include genetics, infection with Epstein-Barr virus, air pollution, and smoking.

It has three types -

  1. Keratinizing carcinoma
  2. Nonkeratinizing differentiated carcinoma
  3. Nonkeratinizing undifferentiated carcinoma. 

The most common presenting symptom is cervical lymphadenopathy, occurring in 60-90% of cases. The most common site of origin of nasopharyngeal carcinoma is the fossa of Rosenmuller. From here, it can spread extensively in any direction locally. It also can spread lymphatically to the cervical, retropharyngeal, or parapharyngeal lymph nodes. 

Symptoms include:

  • Nasal- Nasal obstruction, denasal speech, nasal discharge, epistaxis.
  • Otologic- unilateral conductive hearing loss, and serous or suppurative otitis media. 
  • Facial pain and reduced corneal reflex- cranial nerve V. (most common cranial nerve to be involved)
  • Squint and diplopia- involvement of cranial nerve VI. 
  • Exophthalmos and blindness- cranial nerve II.
  • Horner's syndrome
  • Cervical lymphadenopathy is the most common presenting symptom.

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma can present with Trotter's triad, which includes:

  • Conductive deafness (eustachian tube blockage),
  • Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia due to involvement of CN V and
  • Palatal paralysis due to involvement of CN X

Enlarged lateral retropharyngeal nodes compress the cranial nerve IX, X, and XI causing jugular foramen syndrome. High-resolution contrast-enhanced CT (HR-CECT) of nose and nasopharynx is the investigation of choice.

Other Options: 

Option A: Grommet insertion + steroids would only treat the middle ear effusion symptomatically without addressing the underlying nasopharyngeal malignancy.

Option C: "Wait and watch" would be inappropriate for a suspected malignancy, as delayed treatment could lead to disease progression.

Option D: Radical neck dissection alone would be incorrect as it doesn't address the primary tumor in the nasopharynx, and NPC is primarily treated with radiotherapy rather than surgery due to its anatomical location and radiosensitivity.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presented to you with complaints of pain over the nose after falling from height. On examination, there is a fracture of the nasal septum. Which of the following instruments would you use during the surgery for this patient?
questions.solution:
The instrument used in the above scenario is the Asch forceps (image 2). It is mainly used to reduce a nasal septum fracture.

Other options:

Option A: Luc’s forceps (image 1) is used in Caldwell Luc operation, submucous resection, and polypectomy.

Option C: Tilley’s forceps (image 3) is used in nasal packing in the epistaxis.

Option D: Citelli’s forceps (image 4) is used for bone punch.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with hoarseness and a low-pitched voice. She is a singer and a known smoker. Her laryngoscopy findings are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The laryngoscopy findings show diffuse bilateral edema of the vocal folds suggestive of Reinke's edema.

It occurs due to edema of the subepithelial space (Reinke’s space) of the vocal cords in the glottis.

Key clinical features

  • History of smoking and/or voice abuse.
  • Hoarseness is the most common symptom.
  • Patients use false cords for voice production and this gives them a low-pitched and rough voice.

On indirect laryngoscopy, both vocal cords show diffuse symmetrical swellings. They appear as fusiform swellings with a pale translucent look. Ventricular bands may appear hyperemic and hypertrophic and may hide the view of the true cords.

Treatment

  • Voice rest and cessation of smoking
  • Decortication of the vocal cords, i.e. removal of a strip of epithelium
  • Speech therapy for proper voice production.

Other options

Option B: Laryngeal papilloma/ squamous papilloma are benign tumors of the larynx caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV type 6 and 11). In children, its called juvenile papillomatosis. Patients present with hoarseness, dyspnea or stridor.

Laryngoscopy shows pinkish to white “grape-like” projections that can be sessile or pedunculate with a visible central vascular core. 

The image below shows laryngeal papilloma. 

Option C: A Vocal polyp is caused by vocal abuse or misuse such as sudden shouting resulting in hemorrhage and submucosal edema. It presents with hoarseness and diplophonia. In case of a large polyp, dyspnea, stridor or choking may occur.

On indirect laryngoscopy, they appear as soft, smooth, mobile, and pedunculated mass arising from the free edge of the vocal cord at the junction between the anterior one-third and posterior two-thirds of the vocal cord. They are mostly unilateral.

The image below shows a vocal polyp.

Option D: Vocal nodules (Singer's or Screamer's nodes) are also caused by vocal abuse or misuse. It most commonly affects teachers, actors, singers, vendors, and talkative school children. Patients complain of hoarseness, vocal fatigue, and neck pain during prolonged talking.

On indirect laryngoscopy, they appear as a greyish or white pin-head-sized mass arising from the free edge of the vocal cord at the junction between anterior one-third and posterior two-third of the vocal cord. They are mostly symmetrical (bilateral).

The image below shows symmetrical vocal nodules.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the hypopharynx?
questions.solution:
Vallecula is present in the oropharynx and not laryngopharynx.

The hypopharynx or the laryngopharynx extends from the superior border of the epiglottis to the inferior border of the cricoid cartilage. It is separated from the oropharynx by the lateral glossoepiglottic folds.

The anterior wall is made by the parts of the laryngeal inlet, posterior surfaces of the arytenoid and cricoid cartilages.

Pyriform fossae are present between the aryepiglottic folds medially and thyroid cartilage, thyrohyoid membrane laterally.

  • They serve as channels that direct the solid and liquid food from the oral cavity into the esophagus.
  • Branches of internal laryngeal nerve lie beneath the mucous membrane of the piriform fossa. Hence this site can be used for infiltrating the local anaesthetics.

questions.text: What type of tympanogram is expected in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Image shows fluid in the middle ear, i.e., serous otitis media.

In such condition, compliance, i.e., ease of mobility of tympanic membrane decreases and hence resulting in a B curve. 

Fluid collection is usually secondary to negative middle ear pressure (Eustachian tube obstruction).

Tympanometry is an objective test of the middle ear and Eustachian tube functions (conductive compartment of hearing). Here, the compliance of the TM, i.e., how much it moves to the pressure differentials applied from the external ear is measured.

 

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: A second-year resident performs the tuning fork tests on a patient with hearing loss. The Rinne test is positive in both ears and Weber is lateralized towards the right. What is the interpretation?
questions.solution:
The patient has left-sided sensorineural deafness.

Rinne's test is positive on both ears implying that there is no conductive hearing loss. But there could still be sensorineural hearing loss in either or both ears.

Weber's test lateralized towards the right indicates either right-sided conductive hearing loss or left-sided sensorineural hearing loss. Since there is no conductive deafness which was inferred from Rinnes's test, the interpretation here is left-sided sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with unilateral nasal obstruction. To check for patency of the nasal valve, a Cottle test is performed. In which of the following cases is the test positive?
questions.solution:
Cottle test is positive in patients with a deviated nasal septum. It is used to assess the patency of the nasal valve and when positive, it indicates the abnormality in the vestibular component of the nasal valve.

In this test, the cheek is drawn laterally while the patient breathes quietly. If the nasal airway improves and the obstruction is relieved on the test side, the test is positive and indicates the surgery will be useful and the patient can be taken up for surgery.

The nasal valve area is the narrowest portion of the nasal passage. It is bounded medially by the nasal septum, superiorly and laterally by the caudal margin of the upper lateral cartilage, inferiorly by the floor of the piriform aperture and the nasal valve is the specific slit-like segment between the caudal margin of the upper lateral cartilage and the septum.

Conditions with a positive Cottle test:

  • Deviated nasal septum
  • Collapsed nasal valve - causes snoring and sleep apnoea
  • Valve stenosis

The below image depicts Cottle's test

The deviated nasal septum (DNS) may be caused by two main factors, trauma or developmental errors in addition to being dependent on racial and hereditary factors. Patients present with nasal obstruction, headache, sinusitis, and epistaxis and may manifest an external deformity as well.

Anatomically, DNS can be of various types

  • Anterior dislocation or the septal cartilage into one of the chambers
  • C-shaped deformity: the chamber on the concave side of the nasal septum will be wider and show compensatory hypertrophy of turbinates
  • S-shaped deformity: may cause bilateral nasal obstruction
  • Spur: a shelf-like projection often found at the junction of bone and cartilage
  • Thickening: thickening of a septum due to an organised hematoma may also cause obstruction

Treatment of DNS depends on the severity of symptoms. If asymptomatic, no treatment is required. When DNS causes a mechanical obstruction, submucosal resection or septoplasty (more conservative) may be done.

Other options:

Epistaxis refers to bleeding into the nasal cavity and most commonly occurs in the little's area in the anteroinferior part of the nasal septum. Cottle test to relieve nasal obstruction has no role here. Trotter's method is used as a first aid to arrest bleeding from the little's area.

Atrophic rhinitis refers to chronic inflammation of the nose with atrophy of nasal mucosa. The patients may present with nasal obstruction due to the crusting filling the roomy nasal cavity. Removal of the crust may relieve the obstruction but has the risk of bleeding.

The nasal polyp occurs due to edematous nasal mucosa. It can be an antrochoanal polyp arising from the mucosa of the maxillary antrum or an ethmoidal polyp arising from the middle meatus in the lateral wall of the nose. These polyps appear as globular mass and can be differentiated from turbinate hypertrophy by a probe test. Nasal obstruction resulting from polyps get resolved by conservative or surgical management.

questions.text: A male patient presents with a sore throat and difficulty swallowing for 2 days. On oropharyngeal examination, a grey-white membrane is observed over the tonsils. All of the following are differential diagnoses for membrane over the tonsils except
questions.solution:
All the above-mentioned options are the differential diagnosis for membrane over the tonsils except Ludwig’s angina. Ludwig’s angina is the infection of the submandibular space.

The differential diagnosis for grey membrane over the tonsils includes the following

  • Streptococcus & other pyogenic organisms
  • Diphtheria
  • Infectious mononucleosis
  • Vincent’s angina
  • Leukemia
  • Candida
  • Agranulocytosis
  • Malignancy
  • Aphthous ulcer
  • Traumatic ulcer

 The image given below shows acute tonsillitis presenting with a membrane over the tonsil.

The image given below shows pseudomembrane over tonsil typically seen in diphtheria.

The image given below shows oral candidiasis.

Ludwig’s angina is the infection of the submandibular space. The space lies between the mucous membrane of the floor of the mouth and tongue on one side and the superficial layer of deep cervical fascia extending between the hyoid bone and mandible on the other. It is most commonly caused by dental infections

Clinically, patients present with difficulty in swallowing (odynophagia) and trismus. On examination, the floor of the mouth is swollen and the tongue is pushed up and back. The submental and submandibular space becomes swollen, tender, and has a woody-hard feel.

Complications of this condition include the spread of infection to the parapharyngeal space, retropharyngeal space, and the mediastinum, airway obstruction, septicemia, and aspiration pneumonia.

questions.text:
Match the following signs and the diseases in which they occur.
Signs Diseases
  1. Hennebert's sign
  2. Schwartz sign
  3. Hitzelberger sign
  4. Bryce's sign
  1. Laryngocele
  2. Congenital syphilis
  3. Otosclerosis
  4. Acoustic neuroma
questions.solution:
The correctly matched pair is 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a.

1 - Hennebert's sign in congenital syphilis

Hennebert's sign is a positive fistula sign (nystagmus occurring on applying positive and negative pressure in the external auditory canal) in the absence of a fistula seen in congenital syphilis due to the formation of adhesions between stapes footplate and saccule. It is also seen in a few cases of Meniere's disease.

This is not to be confused with Hennebert's phenomenon which is disequilibrium following nose blowing or lifting a heavy object. It is seen in the perilymph fistula.

2 - Schwartz sign in otosclerosis

A pink or reddish hue seen on the promontory through the tympanic membrane is called the Schwartz sign. It is seen in active otosclerosis.

The image below shows the Schwartz sign.

3 - Hitzelberger sign in acoustic neuroma

Numbness in the posterosuperior meatal wall of the external auditory canal (supplied by the VII cranial nerve) is known as the Hitzelberger sign. It is due to the involvement of the VII cranial nerve in acoustic neuroma.

4 - Bryce's sign in laryngocele

The gurgling sound produced on pressing the swelling in the laryngocele is known as Bryce's sign.

questions.text: A female patient presents with nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and loss of smell. On examination of the nose, she has roomy nasal cavities, foul-smelling discharge, and dry greenish crusts. She is also found to have merciful anosmia. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of merciful anosmia, foul-smelling discharge, and roomy nasal cavities, with dry greenish crusts, points to a diagnosis of atrophic rhinitis.

Atrophic rhinitis is a chronic inflammation of the nose characterized by atrophy of nasal mucosa and turbinate bones. The exact etiology of this condition is not known. It is more common in females and starts around puberty. 

Clinically patients present with nasal obstruction, foul odor, and merciful anosmia. Merciful anosmia is when the patient has marked anosmia and is unable to smell the foul odor coming from their nose.

On examination of the nose, greenish or greyish crusting of the nasal passage, pale nasal mucosa, atrophied nasal turbinates, and epistaxis following the removal of the crusts. The roomy nasal cavity is seen due to the resorption of bones of the turbinates.

Treatment:

  • Nasal irrigation - using warm saline or an alkaline solution composed of sodium bicarbonate 1 part, sodium biborate 1 part, and sodium chloride 2 parts in 280 mL of water
  • Local antibiotics - Kemicetine antiozaena solution containing chloromycetin, oestradiol, and vitamin D2. 
  • 25% glucose in glycerine, estradiol spray, systemic use of streptomycin, potassium iodide, and placental extract.
  • Surgical management:
    • Young's operation.
    • Modified young operation.
    • Narrowing of the nasal cavity can be done by submucosal injection of Teflon paste, or by insertion of fat, cartilage, or Teflon strips under the mucoperiosteum.

Other options:

Option B: Nasal polyps are non-neoplastic masses of the edematous nasal or sinus mucosa. Nasal polyps can be antrochoanal polyps or ethmoidal polyps. They present with a polypoid mass in the nose.

Option C: Allergic rhinitis is associated with inferior turbinate hypertrophy and can cause chronic nasal obstruction. It is characterized by watery nasal discharge, sneezing, and itching in the nose.

Option D: Foreign body nose is commonly seen in children. The child presents with unilateral, foul-smelling nasal discharge.

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Atrophic Rhinitis

  • More common in females 
  • Usually starts at puberty
  • It is a bilateral condition
  • Symptoms:
    • Foul smell from the nose
    • Nasal obstruction in spite of roomy chambers due to large crusts filling nasal cavity
    • Epistaxis on removing of the crusts
    • Anosmia due to degeneration of nerve elements (merciful anosmia)
  • Signs:
    • Greenish or greyish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum
    • After removal of crusts, nasal cavities appear roomy with atrophy of turbinates
    • Nasal mucosa appears pale

questions.text: CNS infections can spread to inner ear through
questions.solution: Scala tympani is connected with the subarachnoid space through the aqueduct of cochlea. Infection spreads from inner ear to CNS or vice versa through this route.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents with right-sided nasal obstruction and occasional blood-stained nasal discharge. His CT and endoscopy findings are shown in the below image. What could be the underlying cause?
questions.solution:
On the basis of the given images, inverted papilloma could be the most likely underlying cause.

Inverted papilloma (Ringertz tumor or transitional cell papilloma or Schneiderian papilloma) is a benign neoplasm of the non-olfactory mucosa of the nose (also called the Schneiderian membrane) and paranasal sinuses.

The lateral wall of the nose in the middle meatus is the most common site of origin. The hyperplastic papillomatous tissue grows into the stroma.
It is common in the 4th to 7th decades of life with a male preponderance. It is almost always unilateral and presents with unilateral nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and epistaxis. It can invade sinuses or the orbit, the latter of which causes proptosis, diplopia, and lacrimation.
 
On examination of nose or endoscopy, it presents as a polypoidal mass resembling simple nasal polyps, as depicted by arrows in the endoscopic image above. A computed tomography(CT) scan and/or magnetic resonance imaging(MRI) show the location and extent of the lesion. MRI provides additional help to differentiate associated secretions in the sinus from the actual tumor mass. A biopsy is essential for diagnosis.
 
Medial maxillectomy is the treatment of choice, done preferably via endoscopy. Recurrence is common and malignancy has been observed in up to 15% of the cases.
 
Other options:
 
Option B: Carcinoma maxilla arises from the lining of the maxillary sinus and its early features include additional symptoms like facial paraesthesias, pain, or epiphora and depending on the direction of spread of the growth, would cause additional symptoms.
 
Option C: Esthesioneuroblastoma (olfactory neuroblastoma) arises from the olfactory epithelium in the upper third of the nose. It has bimodal peaks of incidence at 10–20 years and 50–60 years. Unilateral nasal obstruction and epistaxis are the most common symptoms. The tumour also invades the orbit and the surrounding structures, which results in other symptoms like proptosis, headache, epiphora, diplopia, and blurred vision.
 
Option D: Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is seen almost exclusively in males in the age group of 10–20 years and is very rarely seen in older people and females. Profuse, recurrent, and spontaneous epistaxis is the most common presentation.

questions.text: Where is the electrode placed in cochlear implant procedures?
questions.solution:
The electrode of a cochlear implant is placed in the scala tympani.

A cochlear implant is a medical device that uses electricity to stimulate the spiral ganglion cells of the auditory nerve to restore sensorineural hearing loss. It converts sound to an electrical signal (transduction) and delivers this to the hearing nerve, which bypasses the damaged hearing apparatus. It cannot be used in patients with cochlear aplasia or without the VIIIth cranial nerve.

Cochlear implant:

  • An electronic device for severe to profound SNHL and who cannot benefit from a hearing aid.
  • Principle- surgery to place the electrode array within the scala tympani of the cochlea.
  • Indication- bilateral severe to profound deafness
  • Prerequisites- intact 8th nerve and higher auditory pathway
  • Surgical approach- facial recess (posterior tympanotomy) approach
  • The electrode of a cochlear implant is placed in the scala tympani. (Note: In the auditory brainstem implant, the site of the implant is the lateral recess of the 4th ventricle.)

The receiver-stimulator implanted during surgery (under the skin) and the electrode array (implanted in the scala tympani of the cochlea) are part of the internal component of the cochlear implant. Microphone, speech processor, and transmitter are part of the external component of the cochlear implant, which remains outside the body.

Cochlear implants replace the non-functional transducer system of hair cells of the cochlea and convert the sound signal to electrical impulses, which directly stimulate the fibers of cranial nerve VIII.

In stage T1b N0 M0 laryngeal cancer, both the vocal cords are involved and are mobile.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the treatment of Bell’s palsy?
questions.solution:
• Steroids - Prednisolone is the drug of choice. If patient reports within 1 week, the adult dose of prednisolone is 1 mg/kg/day divided into morning and evening doses for 5 days.
  • Steroids can be combined with acyclovir for Herpes zoster oticus or if viral etiology is suspected in Bell’s palsy.
  • Care of the eye – most important. Eye must be protected against exposure keratitis.
  • Physiotherapy with electro-stimulation and massage of the facial muscles gives psychological support to the patient.

questions.text: A patient with bilateral abductor paralysis is admitted to the intensive care unit. In order to relieve the respiratory obstruction, a tracheostomy is being performed. Which of the following is not an immediate complication of this procedure?
questions.solution:
Tracheal stenosis, due to tracheal ulceration and infection, is a late complication of tracheostomy and does not occur immediately.

A tracheostomy is a procedure where an opening is made in the anterior wall of the trachea and it is converted into a stoma on the skin surface. It is primarily indicated when there is respiratory obstruction, secretions, or respiratory insufficiency. It is also indicated in an intubated patient after 2-3 weeks to avoid subglottic stenosis.

Complications of tracheostomy:

Immediate

(at the time of operation)

Intermediate

(during first few hours or days)

Late

(after chronic use for weeks or months)
  1. Primary hemorrhage
  2. Apnoea due to sudden washout of CO2
  3. Pneumothorax due to injury to apical pleura
  4. Injury to recurrent laryngeal nerves
  5. Aspiration of blood
  6. Injury to esopgahus
  1. Reactionary or secondary hemorrhage.
  2. Displacement of the tube.
  3. Blocking of the tube.
  4. Subcutaneous emphysema.
  5. Tracheitis and tracheobronchitis.
  6. Atelectasis and lung abscess.
  7. Local wound infection and granulations.
  1. Laryngeal stenosis.
  2. Tracheal stenosis
  3. Tracheo-oesophageal fistula
  4. Problems of decannulation.
  5. Persistent tracheocutaneous fistula.
  6. Keloid or unsightly scar.
  7. Aspiration of tracheostomy tube fragments into the tracheobronchial tree

 

 

Mentioned below are some instruments used during the procedure. 

Cuffed tracheostomy tube:

  • It has an outer tube, an inner tube, and an obturator.
  • Presence of cuff prevents aspiration of pharyngeal secretions into the trachea and also prevents air-leak. 
  • Cuff should be deflated every 2 h for 5 min to prevent ischaemia and damage to the trachea and cartilage necrosis.

Uses:

  • Tracheostomy in an unconscious patient or in a patient on a respirator.

 

Tracheal dilator is used to keep the tracheal edges open after incision in the trachea so that tracheostomy tube can be easily inserted. 

Related Pearl: Types of Tracheostomy

High tracheostomy

  • Done through the 1st tracheal ring
  • An opening is made above the isthmus of the thyroid gland 
  • Done in case of malignancy of the larynx
  • Increased risk of perichondritis and subglottic stenosis

Mid tracheostomy

  • Done through the 2nd - 3rd rings
  • Most commonly done tracheostomy
  • Isthmus has to be retracted or divided

Low tracheostomy

  • Done through the 4th - 5th tracheal ring
  • Done below the isthmus
  • Done when the airway is blocked at an upper airway level
  • Risk of injuring the great vessels of the neck

questions.text: What is the instrument shown below?
questions.solution:
The instrument shown is Barany’s noise box, which masks the non-test ear while testing bone conduction.

Other options:

Option A: Meniett device is a small, portable pulse generator that can control vertigo in patients with Ménière's disease.

Option C: A portable audiometer is a device used to screen hearing loss in settings such as small clinics and homes. An image of a portable audiometer is shown below.

Option D: Higginson syringe is used to wash the antrum after an antral puncture is done. This device is shown in the image below.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents to the ENT surgeon with a history of vertigo whenever she moves sideways on the bed while lying supine. She feels nauseous and as if the room is spinning. The symptoms subside after a few minutes but return when she moves her head. Which of the following tests is most appropriate to diagnose this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). The diagnostic maneuver used in BPPV is the Dix-Hallpike maneuver, the gold standard for diagnosing BPPV. The therapeutic maneuver is Epley's maneuver.

BPPV is one of the common causes of recurrent vertigo, and the episodes are brief (<1min) and are always provoked by changes in head position. The attacks are caused by free-floating calcium carbonate crystals usually dislodged from the posterior canal.

A patient presenting with vertigo should be evaluated for ruling out the central lesions (like a tumor in the fourth ventricle, multiple sclerosis, etc) before confirming the diagnosis of BPPV. Dix-Hallpike maneuver helps rule out central lesions and also diagnose BPPV.

Dix-Hallpike maneuver:

  1. The maneuver starts with the patient in a sitting position.
  2. Their head is turned 45 degrees towards the ear to be tested.
  3. The examiner quickly brings the patient to a supine position with their head 30 degrees below the horizontal.
  4. The 45-degree head rotation is maintained during the procedure.
  5. Now the examiner observes the patient for nystagmus.

questions.text: A young adult presents with intermittent non-foul smelling mucoid discharge from the left ear for the past few years. Otologic examination revealed a central perforation of the tympanic membrane. Which of the following statements is false regarding his condition?

choices.text: No evidence of bone destruction in CT scans
Mixed aerobic and anaerobic infections are seen
Aural polyp if present, should never be avulsed

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of intermittent mucoid discharge and central perforation of the tympanic membrane points to a diagnosis of tubotympanic type of CSOM, which is not associated with cholesteatoma. Atticoantral type is associated with cholesteatoma and it leads to dangerous complications due to its bone-eroding properties. 

Etiology of tubotympanic (benign or safe) type of CSOM:

  • As a sequela of acute otitis media
  • Ascending infection via the eustachian tube
  • Allergic conditions

Bone destruction is not present in this type.

Culture reveals mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection.

Aural polyp if present should be removed and not avulsed before starting local treatment. This is due to the fact that the polyp may be arising from the stapes, facial nerve, or horizontal canal and its avulsion can lead to facial paralysis or labyrinthitis.

questions.text: A 35 year old male presented to the clinic with complaints of  episodic vertigo,  sense of ear pressure and fullness, decreased hearing, and a low-tone roaring tinnitus. What is the possible clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The possible clinical diagnosis for a 35-year-old male presenting with episodic vertigo, ear pressure and fullness, decreased hearing, and low-tone roaring tinnitus is Meniere's disease. It is also called endolymphatic hydrops.

The primary pathology in Ménière’s disease is the distension of the endolymphatic system due to an increased endolymph volume. This can result either from increased production of endolymph or its faulty absorption or both. Normally, endolymph secreted by stria vascularis, fills the membranous labyrinth, and is absorbed through the endolymphatic sac.

Meniere's disease is a chronic condition of the inner ear that affects balance and hearing. It is characterized by recurrent episodes of vertigo, which are brief and intense episodes of spinning dizziness. Patients may also experience a sense of pressure or fullness in the affected ear, along with fluctuating hearing loss and tinnitus (ringing or buzzing in the ear). The tinnitus associated with Meniere's disease is typically low-tone roaring in nature.

Other options:

  • Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) is another common cause of vertigo, but it is characterized by brief episodes of vertigo triggered by specific head movements, such as rolling over in bed or looking up. BPPV does not typically cause ear pressure, hearing loss, or low-tone roaring tinnitus.
  • Labyrinthitis is an inflammation of the inner ear, usually caused by a viral or bacterial infection. It can cause vertigo, hearing loss, and tinnitus, but it is usually accompanied by other symptoms such as ear pain, fever, and a general feeling of illness.
  • Syncope refers to a temporary loss of consciousness and muscle tone, often caused by a decrease in blood flow to the brain. It is not associated with the symptoms described in the scenario, such as vertigo, ear pressure, hearing loss, or tinnitus.

questions.text: A 35- year old woman presented to the clinic with the symptoms of hearing loss and pulsatile tinnitus. Further examination reveals conductive hearing loss with Rinne test negative. A reddish mass is seen behind the tympanic membrane. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of a glomus tumor.

Glomus tumor is the most common benign middle ear neoplasm. It is seen frequently in middle-aged females. The tumor consists of paraganglionic cells from the neural crest. Glomus tumor is an extremely vascular benign tumor.

There are two types of glomus tumors: glomus jugulare and glomus tympanicum. Glomus jugulare arises from the dome of the jugular bulb and invades the hypotympanum. Glomus tympanicum arises from the promontory of the middle ear.

Clinical features include conductive hearing loss and pulsatile tinnitus- earliest symptoms. Otoscopy examination shows a red reflex through an intact tympanic membrane as a "rising sun" appearance since the tumor arises from the floor of the middle ear. Paralysis of the 9th to 12th cranial nerves can also occur. An audible bruit over the mastoid is heard on auscultation in all the stages of the tumor.

Other options:

Option A: Acute otitis media presents with throbbing earache and a red and bulging tympanic membrane with loss of landmarks on examination. Tuning fork tests reveal a conductive type of hearing loss.

Option B: Chronic otitis media presents with mucoid or mucopurulent ear discharge, the conductive type of hearing loss, and central perforation of the tympanic membrane. Middle ear mucosa can be seen through the perforation.  

Option D: Serous otitis media presents with hearing loss, delayed and defective speech, and mild earaches associated with upper respiratory tract infections. Otoscopy reveals a dull, opaque, and retracted tympanic membrane with loss of light reflex, a thin leash of vessels along the handle of the malleus, fluid levels, and air bubbles behind the tympanic membrane.

questions.text: What is this view called in which maxillary sinus is seen best?
questions.solution:
Occipitomental view with an open mouth is also called the water’s view.

Water's view: The patient’s head is positioned such that the nose and the chin touch the film while the X-rays are projected from backward. The mouth is usually kept open while taking the X-ray.

Structures seen in water’s view are:

  • Maxillary sinuses (seen best)
  • Frontal sinuses
  • Sphenoid sinus (if the film is taken with open mouth)
  • Zygoma
  • Zygomatic arch
  • Nasal bone
  • Frontal process of maxilla
  • Superior orbital fissure
  • Infratemporal fossa

Related Pearl: Radiographic views of paranasal sinuses and mastoid

questions.text: A middle-aged patient presents with multiple nodules in the nasal mucosa. Biopsy from the nodules revealed the presence of Miculikz cells and Russell bodies. Which of the following is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the biopsy findings showing Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies are characteristic of rhinoscleroma.

Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis (Frisch bacillus).

Mikulicz cells are large foam cells with a central nucleus and vacuolated cytoplasm containing causative bacilli. Russell bodies are homogenous eosinophilic inclusion bodies found in the plasma cells due to the accumulation of immunoglobulins secreted by plasma cells. Histology also shows infiltration of submucosa with plasma cells, lymphocytes and eosinophils. 

The following image shows rhinoscleroma with Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies(marked in black arrows)

Rhinoscleroma starts in the nose and extends to the nasopharynx, oropharynx, subglottic larynx, trachea and bronchi. It has 3 stages:

  1. Atrophic stage– Crusting and foul-smelling nasal discharge similar to atrophic rhinitis.
  2. Granulomatous stage– Painless, non-ulcerative granulomatous nodules with subdermal infiltration giving the feel of a woody nose.
  3. Cicatricial stage – Fibrosis leading to stenosis of vestibule, pharynx and larynx. 

Treatment is done by the use of antibiotics streptomycin and tetracycline for 4 to 6 weeks. Steroids to reduce fibrosis. Surgical intervention may be required to restore the airway and correct the nasal deformity. Treatment is stopped only when two consecutive cultures from the biopsy are negative. 

Other options:

Option B: Rhinosporidiosis is a granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi characterised by multiple polypoidal growths. The biopsy shows several oval or round-shaped sporangia filled with spores bursting through the chitinous walls.

Option C: Lupus vulgaris is a low-grade tuberculosis infection characterised by chronic vestibulitis and perforation of the nasal septum. Biopsy shows tuberculous granuloma and caseous necrosis.

Option D: Granulomatosis with polyangitis is a chronic granulomatous disorder presenting with crusting, granulation and saddle deformity of the nose. Biopsy shows necrosis and ulceration of mucosa, epithelioid granuloma and necrotizing vasculitis of the vessels.

questions.text: During syringing, water jet is directed along ______
questions.solution:
Syringing: Pinna is pulled upwards and backwards and a stream of water from the ear syringe is directed along the posterosuperior wall of the meatus.

This is derived from 2 anatomic facts:

  • The posteroinferior wall of EAC is supplied by the vagus nerve. Direct stimulation of this can lead to sudden cardiac arrest.
  • On manoeuvring the pinna to bring the EAC into a straight configuration, the posterior wall is straighter and easily accessible than the anterior wall.

Therefore, the direction of choice for the jet of water is along the posterosuperior wall. 

Complications

  • Vertigo – caloric stimulation of lateral semicircular canal if water is too hot or too cold.
  • Rupture of TM.
  • Reactivation of quiescent otitis media (if there is pre-existing perforation).

Contraindications for syringing

  • Presence of ear infection, TM perforation
  • Presence of grommet or H/O ear surgery

questions.text: An elderly diabetic female patient presented with a black, foul-smelling discharge from the nose. On examination, a blackish necrotic mass is seen filling the nasal cavity and eroding the septum and hard palate. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Mucormycosis.

Diabetic patients with local tissue destruction with blackish nasal discharge typically resembles the presentation of invasive mucormycosis. The blackish discolouration is due to direct fungal invasion causing arterial and venous thrombosis leading to gangrene. Mucormycosis is an opportunistic infection caused principally by species of Rhizopus, Mucor, and Lichtheimia. The most prevalent species is Rhizopus Oryza. 

Risk factors:

  • Diabetes (Diabetic ketoacidosis).
  • Immunocompromised individuals

Treatment:

  • Intravenous administration of amphotericin B is the treatment of choice for invasive mucormycosis.
  • Surgical debridement
  • Control of underlying predisposing causes.

Other options:

Option A: Invasive aspergillosis leads to the formation of black or greyish membrane in the nasal mucosa. The maxillary sinus may contain a fungus ball containing semisolid cheesy-white or blackish material.

Option C: Foreign body nose presents with foul-smelling unilateral discharge.

Option D: Rhinosporidiosis is a granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi and presents with nasal discharge, epistaxis, and nasal obstruction by a polypoidal mass.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy who was treated for acute otitis media 2 weeks back presents with fever,  and pain behind his right ear. On examination, tenderness is present over the mastoid and the pinna is pushed anteriorly suggesting acute mastoiditis. A fluctuant swelling is present between the tip of the mastoid and the angle of the jaw. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along is most likely suggestive of the diagnosis of Bezold's abscess.

Bezold abscess is defined as a complication of acute coalescent mastoiditis and is formed when pus breaks inferiorly, through the thin medial aspect of the tip of the mastoid and collects in the upper part of the neck, most commonly into the sheath of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. The abscess can also take any of the following locations: 

  • Deep to the sternocleidomastoid
  • Along the posterior belly of the digastric presenting as a swelling in the tip of the mastoid or the angle of the jaw
  • The upper part of the posterior triangle
  • Parapharyngeal space
  • Along with the carotid vessels.

Treatment:

  1. Cortical mastoidectomy for coalescent mastoiditis
  2. Drainage of the abscess in the neck with insertion of a drain through a separate incision
  3. IV antibiotics

Other options:

Option A: Zygomatic abscess forms due to infection of the zygomatic air cells. It is situated at the posterior root of the zygoma.  Patients present with swelling in front and above the pinna with associated edema over the upper eyelid. Here the pus collects either superficial or deep to the temporalis muscle.

Option C: Luc abscess is defined as a subperiosteal temporal abscess. It develops following the spread of infection from the middle ear along the external auditory meatus, directly, to the temporal region. Swelling is present in the deep part of the bony meatus. 

Option D: Citelli’s abscess is formed posterior to the mastoid, occupying a position more towards the occipital bone. It is also considered an abscess of the digastric triangle. In any case, a diagnosis of Bezold abscess is more appropriate for this patient owing to the location of the abscess.

questions.text: Superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome is associated with all except:
questions.solution:
Sensorineural hearing loss is not seen in superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome (SSCDS)

Superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome

  • Occurs due to the third window effect that gets created because of the thin/ dehiscent wall of the superior semicircular canal.
  • Endolymph in the labyrinthine system move in relation to sound or pressure, causing an activation of the vestibular system.
  • Diagnosed in middle-aged individuals.
  • Noise or pressure-induced dizziness ,chronic imbalance, avoidance of noisy environments.
  • Gaze-evoked tinnitus and/or hyperacusis. 
  • Tulio phenomenon(sound or pressure-induced vestibular activation).
  • Fistula test is positive(Hennebert Sign)
  • Noncontrast HRCT of the temporal bone can demonstrate the defect
  • Treated by surgery if there are severe disabling symptoms else conservative medical management.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman complains of progressive hearing loss, which aggravated during pregnancy. Pure tone audiometry reveals a Carhart's notch and she is diagnosed with otosclerosis. Identify the procedure done for this patient's condition.
questions.solution:
The above image shows a stapedotomy procedure performed in the middle ear.

It can be identified as a stapedotomy procedure by the following features in the image given:

  • The footplate of the stapes is not removed
  • The prosthesis is placed by creating a hole in the footplate of the stapes

Stapedotomy is the excision of the superstructure of stapes and drilling a hole in the footplate & placing a piston in the hole. It is done to bypass the immobile stapes using a piston which will take over the function of conducting sound.

Contraindications for Stapedotomy:

  • Only hearing ear
  • Positive Schwartze sign
  • Otitis externa
  • Meniere’s disease: can damage the inner ear while drilling a hole in the footplate
  • Young children
  • Professional athletes, pilots, construction workers, divers: Sudden change in pressure can displace the piston and cause vertigo.
  • Those who work in noisy surroundings: Surgery makes them more vulnerable to noise-induced hearing loss.

Otosclerosis is a primary disease of the bony labyrinth where foci of irregularly placed spongy bone replace part of the normally dense enchondral layer of the bony otic capsule. It is more commonly seen in females between 20-30 years of age and the hearing loss is aggravated during pregnancy and menopause.

Clinically, patients present with painless progressive bilateral conductive hearing loss and paracusis willisii (patient hears better in noisy surroundings as other people raise their voice to be heard). 

Tuning fork tests and audiometry will reveal the presence of conductive hearing loss. The bone conduction curve may show a dip, which is maximum at 2000Hz, known as Carhart’s notch.

The image shown below shows Carhart's notch.

Other options:

Options B and C: Stapes mobilization and Lempert’s fenestration operation are older procedures seldom performed these days.

Option D: Stapedectomy involves complete removal of the anterior and posterior portions of the footplate, leaving the membrane below the footplate intact. Now the oval window with its overlying membrane is covered with a piece of fascia and the prosthesis is placed over this.

questions.text: Treatment of choice for acoustic neuroma is______
questions.solution:
• Surgical removal of the tumor is the treatment of choice.
  • The approach depends upon site and size of tumor:
    • Middle Cranial fossa approach
    • Translabyrinthine approach
    • Retrosigmoid/Suboccipital approach
    • Combined
